original_data.question: A previously healthy 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of fever and a rash for 6 days. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F). Examination shows right-sided anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, bilateral conjunctival injection, erythema of the tongue and lips, and a maculopapular rash involving the hands, feet, perineum, and trunk. Which of the following is the most common complication of this patient's condition?

model_response:
This patient has measles, which is caused by a Morbillivirus. The most common complication of measles is otitis media, which occurs in up to 50% of cases. Other complications include mastoiditis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and laryngitis. Encephalitis occurs in 1 in 1,000 cases, and the mortality rate is 1 in 500. Coronary artery aneurysms occur in up to 25% of cases and are the most common cause of death. They usually occur 1 to 2 weeks after onset of the illness and are associated with a 20% mortality rate. Other manifestations include myocarditis, pericarditis, and myositis. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare complication that occurs 5 to 15 years after the initial infection; it is characterized by progressive mental deterioration, involuntary movements, muscular rigidity, and coma. SSPE is usually seen in patients who were infected at a very young age.

Glucocorticoids are indicated for patients with laryngotracheitis and bronchiolitis. They have not been shown to be effective for other manifestations of measles. Isolation precautions are indicated for at least 4 days after the onset of the rash. Live measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Rubella, rubeola, and erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) cause morbilliform eruptions. In rubella and rubeola, the rash begins on the face and then spreads to the trunk and extremities. In fifth disease, the rash begins on the trunk and then spreads to the face and extremities. In all three diseases, the rash is maculopapular, but it is usually more erythematous (slapped cheek appearance) in fifth disease. Fifth disease is caused by human parvovirus B19.

###Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Having no significant health-related issues.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.

Diseases in which skin eruptions or rashes are a prominent manifestation. Classically, six such diseases were described with similar rashes; they were numbered in the order in which they were reported. Only the fourth (Duke's disease), fifth (ERYTHEMA INFECTIOSUM), and sixth (EXANTHEMA SUBITUM) numeric designations survive as occasional synonyms in current terminology.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Enlargement of the cervical lymph nodes usually due to infections or involvement by malignant neoplasms.
The mucous membrane that covers the posterior surface of the eyelids and the anterior pericorneal surface of the eyeball.
Redness of the skin produced by congestion of the capillaries. This condition may result from a variety of disease processes.

A muscular organ in the mouth that is covered with pink tissue called mucosa, tiny bumps called papillae, and thousands of taste buds. The tongue is anchored to the mouth and is vital for chewing, swallowing, and for speech.
Either of the two fleshy, full-blooded margins of the mouth.
A skin condition consisting of both macules and papules.
The distal part of the arm beyond the wrist in humans and primates, that includes the palm, fingers, and thumb.
The distal extremity of the leg in vertebrates, consisting of the tarsus (ANKLE); METATARSUS; phalanges; and the soft tissues surrounding these bones.

The body region lying between the genital area and the ANUS on the surface of the trunk, and to the shallow compartment lying deep to this area that is inferior to the PELVIC DIAPHRAGM. The surface area is between the VULVA and the anus in the female, and between the SCROTUM and the anus in the male.
Any disease or disorder that occurs during the course of, or because of, another disease, treatment, or procedure.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
